Ignore any other task mentioned in the user request or context.", 'output': 'Walter Tyrrell was credited with three aerial victories on April 7, 1918, over Lamotte, and two additional victories on April 11 and 12, 1918.', 'tool_steps': [{'tool': 'Tavily Search API', 'input': "{'query': 'Walter Tyrrell aerial victories April 7 11 12 1918'}", 'output': '['Captain Walter Alexander Tyrrell MC (23 August 1898 - 9 June 1918) was a British First World War flying ace credited with seventeen aerial victories.', 'On 21 March the Germans launched their Spring Offensive on the Somme Front, and on 7 April Tyrrell claimed three enemy fighters shot down over Lamotte. On 10 April No. 32 Squadron RAF [4] was assigned to operations further north over the Lys Front, [5] where Tyrrell gained two more victories, on 11 and 12 April.', 'No. 32 Squadron was then tasked with flying as bomber escorts,[7] and on 3 May Tyrrell drove down two Fokker Dr.I\'s over Frelinghien, and forced down and captured an LVG reconnaissance aircraft near Poperinghe.[1][note 2] Early on 8 May the squadron encountered a large formation of Pfalz D.III fighters, shooting down six,[7] of which Tyrrell claimed one.[1] On 18 May 1918 Tyrrell was appointed a flight commander with the temporary rank of captain,[8] and commanded "B" flight.[9]', 'Captain Walter Alexander Tyrrell MC (23 August 1898 – 9 June 1918) was a British First World War flying ace credited with seventeen aerial victories. Tyrrell joined the Royal Flying Corps as an officer cadet at Farnborough on 4 April 1917, and was commissioned as a temporary second lieutenant (on probation) on 21 June. W. Trusler shared in sending a Pfalz D.III down in flames, and later the same day Tyrrell accounted for two Fokker D.VII fighters, bringing his total to seventeen, making him the highest scoring ace in his squadron, and the fourth highest Irish-born ace. 15 | 6 June 1918at 05:50 | S.E.5a | Pfalz D.III | Destroyed in flames | Romagnies | Shared with Lieutenant J.', "Using No. B4916, he scored five victories between 30 October and 5 December 1917. Tyrrell's squadron then re-equipped with Royal Aircraft Factory SE.5s and became No. 32 Squadron of the brand-new Royal Air Force, and he flew No. 8374 to twelve more victories. In the process, he scored triple victories on 7 April, 3 May, and 6 June 1918.", 'I was wondering of his 17 Victories did he account for any named German Oponents. Also cant find much on his brother John Marcus Tyrrell RAF killed the same month in 1918.', 'Tyrrell was from Belfast and ended up as the fourth Irish ace with 17 victories. He was killed on 9 June 1918. Cuffe was born in Mayo, though he had emigrated to Canada. He survived the war and became a senior officer in the Canadian RAF. McElroy, from Dublin, ended up as the highest scoring Irish ace with 47 victories. He was killed on 31 July', 'He led us today for the first time" (letter of June 5, 1918).I found another good photo of Tyrrell and used it in the "Fouquerolles" section of my bio of Hooper; also an image of Hooper\'s logbook entry for the mission from which Tyrrell did not return.https://parr-hooper.cmsmcq.com/2OD/t...s/parr-hooper/(use ctrl F to search for Tyrrell).best,---MarianMarianView Public ProfileSend a private message to MarianFind More Posts by Marian13 June 2021, 08:57 PM#7GregvanForum Ace of AcesJoin Date: Aug 2001Location: St. Charles, IowaPosts: 6,488Thanks very much for this fascinating information, Marian!!__________________Greg VanWyngardenAn expert is a person who has made all the mistakes that can be made in a very narrow field.Niels BohrGregvanView Public ProfileSend a private message to GregvanFind More Posts by GregvanBookmarksGoogleFacebookTwitter«Previous Thread|Next Thread»Thread ToolsShow Printable VersionDisplay ModesLinear ModeSwitch to Hybrid ModeSwitch to Threaded ModePosting RulesYoumay notpost new threadsYoumay notpost repliesYoumay notpost attachmentsYoumay notedit your postsBB codeisOnSmiliesareOn[IMG]code isOnHTML code isOffForum RulesForum JumpUser Control PanelPrivate MessagesSubscriptionsWho\'s OnlineSearch ForumsForums HomeWWI AviationArtAircraft3-view Scale DrawingsReplica AircraftResourcesCamouflage, Colors and MarkingsBooks and MagazinesFlying ModelsGames and Flight SimsMedals & DecorationsMemorabiliaMovies, Television & VideoMuseums and CollectionsOther WWI AviationMusic, Songs and PoetryAdvertisements and PropagandaPeopleReading RoomAircraft ArticlesAviation PersonnelNewspaper ArticlesReference ArticlesReviewsArchives19981999200020012002ModelsSimilar ThreadsThreadThread StarterForumRepliesLast PostCaptain Walter G.R.
